title: What are some metaphors to describe a smile? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, to kick this answer off, I'm sure you've heard the age old example of using the sun as a metaphor for a smile (or was that a simile?..hmmm) This works great because both (especially, if you are speaking with regard to a love interest): are quite radiant;fill one with warmth;possess the power to brighten the day;are indicative of life.  A brief example: ~ Overcast Heart ~ These are new skies — new vibrant hues — A new world brought to life within; For each time she smiles, Rays of glee break through my overcast heart. I could continue, but I think you got it*  The next metaphor I can think of — and I’ll stop at 3 — is stained-glass windows. Bet’cha wondering how that works? ;) Welllll, lettuce see, they both: craftily hide inner turmoil/conflict;are able to be manufactured;are one of the first features you notice on people/architecture;depict character;artistically portray a wide range of emotions/color;can be broken;can contain gaps;often have a history — tell a story;take time to put together;have two sides.  An example: ~ The Girl with the Stained Glass Smile ~ Lazy eyes, burdened with unrest — Ashen mascara to shadow her brow of coal. Those ebbing lamps, Oh! dying flames! A clandestine iniquity, Veils her smiles of glass-stain: Damp skin, ghoulish hues, chalky lips replete with sacred wine; by drip and flow it sates the beast — he breaks her bread in moonlight and consumes it piece by piece. It's a bit dark and eery — such is the history of stained-glass windows — but I wanted to supply you with a versatile stretch of potential usage, as this metaphor could easily be used in a light and cute context, in the same manner the sun metaphor could be used in one which is dark. ~ *P.S. Yes, I realize, this feature is designed for quoting other people…buuut Have you heard of “asides” in Shakespeare's plays? Well, there’ya go :) (Even better than parentheticals! oh..wait…) ~  Now, onto our final metaphor. *drum roll* “Ra-ta-taatatata-doobie-dun-dun-ayee-du---" *odd looks and shrugs get exchanged betwixt the bewildered attending audience and the slightly horrified drum section* “What? Was I sup--ohhhh…yeahhh..” Ahem, *blushing fades slowly* back to my narrator voice. Where were we? Oh, yes.. Our final metaphor is none other than a polaroid picture.  Getting the picture? I just wanted to shake things up a bit — don’t worry, it’s alright if it takes a while for things to become clear, you’ll see it eventually :p I can smell your ruminating through the screen…  “What could the potential parallels be, when you’re using something which generally captures the very smile for which it has now become a metaphor?” Aye, because thou hast beseeched me, I shall extrapolate: Everyone seems to remember a smile, as if it were a momentous polaroid picture hanging upon a clothesline, encapsulating the bond between two people — romantic, friendly, etc.If the smile is the resulting picture printed from the camera — their face — the nose is the button you press *cough* boop *cough* to get it.Just as the picture from a polaroid comes out white when printed, such could be said of a smile from someone you don’t know; however, as you put in the effort and work to get to know the person and make memories with them, the smile changes and develops its own deeper meaning and sentimental value, just as how the polaroid picture becomes clearer the more you shake it.Afterthought on that point: the potential for friendship/romance is captured in every smile, but it will never be realized until initiative and perseverance is taken to see the outcome, whether it turns out good or bad.Like a polaroid picture, there’s a lot that goes into a person’s smile:film — memories and life experiences;ink — emotions and thoughts;buttons — physical interaction;lense — worldview and upbringing;flash — spontaneity and insightIt’s something which is important and meaningful, people love to share it and to see other’s, and they always keep it on them. But even smiles can fade with time, after being passed through so many hands, especially ones who were rough and didn’t value it. Unfortunately, it often becomes hidden: stuffed in an old wallet or drawer; lost in stacks of mail and other internal clutter — regret, hate, sadness, fear, apathy.The clouds converge to obscure the radiant sun as hail rains from above to destroy her stained-glass windows; the polaroids all fade to black and become stained with coffee and tears. We are left only to wonder where the beauty went, where that frugacious smile has gone, and why we could not capture it, and keep it to cherish for just a moment longer.  A final poetry example: ~ Polaroid ~ let me pull you close, until we are eye to eye; i want to see the world from the lenses of your mind. a vintage soul in color — darling you are rare — you remind me of a time, we still have yet to share. and as i rest softly my thumb upon your cheek, my hand will hold your chin as our noses begin to meet. captured on a film, the ink our hearts have bled, i caught that little smile — before i knew, it fled. contagious as a laugh, though, i caught one of my own, and hung it o’er the windows of this love we call our home.  To the Whomsoevers, I hope this helped you out some! Maybe a bit over-the-top in retrospect, but I enjoyed writing it (ntm, I always love a good excuse to write more poems XD) *Attending audience continues in their bewilderment as the drum section remains inert, still petrified in absolute and sheer horror* *looks down* Oh..did I forget to wear clothes again? ~ Caleb  Author’s notes: “deebideebidee th-th-that’s all folks!” — Porky Pig “Hah! See! I did use this mechanism/tool as a quote thingy!” — me Also me — “Pinterest was my source for all of those beauteous pictures up there^^”

Her smile was warm and inviting like a long awaited summer breeze: simile. Warm and inviting, her smile was a long awaited summer breeze-metaphor. A glacier among wildflowers, her smile chilled me to the bone-metaphor. The smile on her beautiful face was like a glacier among wildflowers and chilled me to the bone-simile.
